review.title: A Further Generalization of the Finite-Population Geiringer-like Theorem for POMDPs to Allow Recombination Over Arbitrary Set Covers
review.abstract: A popular current research trend deals with expanding the Monte-Carlo tree search sampling methodologies to the environments with uncertainty and incomplete information. Recently a finite population version of Geiringer theorem with nonhomologous recombination has been adopted to the setting of Monte-Carlo tree search to cope with randomness and incomplete information by exploiting the entrinsic similarities within the state space of the problem. The only limitation of the new theorem is that the similarity relation was assumed to be an equivalence relation on the set of states. In the current paper we lift this "curtain of limitation" by allowing the similarity relation to be modeled in terms of an arbitrary set cover of the set of state-action pairs.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, Monte Carlo sampling methods, such as the Monte Carlo Tree Search, have achieved enormous success in model-free enhancement of learning, perhaps the most famous example being the computer Go software that defeated the leading human actor (see [1], for example). Unlike traditional techniques such as the Mini Max Method (which, by the way, failed for "Go"), the Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCT) is based on performing simulated self-games, known as "rollouts" until the end of the game, when a terminal state has been encountered with a known benefit. A position in a game is represented by a state action pair ~ s = (s, ~ α), where ~ α = (α1, α2,.) is the collection of actions (or movements) available in a position, with the aim of assessing actions through redistribution and aversion. Much effort in current research is devoted to expanding the applicability of the method.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: In the present paper, we have significantly generalized a new version of a Geiringer-like theorem with a limited population and non-homologous recombinations in [3] by making it possible to model similarity relationships across the set of state-action pairs in relation to arbitrary set covers of state-action space (partitions not necessarily induced by equivalence relationships), raising questions about further potential applications of Geiringer-like theorems for decision-making on the design of novel algorithms for pay-off-based clustering.
